case_name: Gouri Prasad Bagaria and others v. Commissioner of Income-tax

facts.text: Appeal is by Gouri Prasad Bagaria and others in respect of the assessment of their father Hanuman Prasad Bagaria.

facts.text: Hanuman Prasad Bagaria referred to as the assessee, his legal representatives as the appellants.

anchor.surface_text: It will be companyvenient to refer to Hanuman Prasad Bagaria as the assessee, and his legal representatives as the appellants. The appeal is directed against the judgment and order of the High Court of Calcutta dated December 14, 1955, in an income-tax reference under section 66 1  of the Indian Income-tax Act.

facts.text: Appeal directed against judgment and order of High Court of Calcutta dated December 14, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is directed against the judgment and order of the High Court of Calcutta dated December 14, 1955, in an income-tax reference under section 66 1  of the Indian Income-tax Act. The High Court answered the question Whether, on the above facts and circumstances of this case,

facts.text: High Court answered the question in the negative.

anchor.surface_text: the assessee purchased gold in the year 1918 which he sold in the year under companysideration and the sum of Rs. 72,523 represents the sale proceeds the sale proceeds of such gold ? in the negative. The facts of the case are simple. For the assessment year 1945-46 companyresponding to the financial year 1944-45 the Income-tax Officer found sum of Rs. 72,523 credited in the name of Ganesh Das Hanuman Prasad,

facts.text: For assessment year 1945-46 corresponding to financial year 1944-45, Income-tax Officer found sum of Rs. 72,523 credited in the name of Ganesh Das Hanuman Prasad, father of the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment year 1945-46 companyresponding to the financial year 1944-45 the Income-tax Officer found sum of Rs. 72,523 credited in the name of Ganesh Das Hanuman Prasad, father of the assessee. The assessee was called upon to explain the nature and source of this amount, and he stated that it represented the sale proceeds of gold purchased by him in 1918 in Bombay,

facts.text: Assessee stated that Rs. 72,523 represented sale proceeds of gold purchased by him in 1918 in Bombay, kept in family chest, sold in account year.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee was called upon to explain the nature and source of this amount, and he stated that it represented the sale proceeds of gold purchased by him in 1918 in Bombay, that the gold was kept in the family chest, and that it was sold in the account year. The entry in the account books in the name of the assessees father was explained as being in accordance with Marwari Custom.

facts.text: Entry in account books in name of assessee's father explained as per Marwari Custom.

anchor.surface_text: The entry in the account books in the name of the assessees father was explained as being in accordance with Marwari Custom. In the pass book of the assessee, there was a withdrawal of Rs. 1,00,000 after a few days, and the assessee explained that the amount was given away to Messrs. Birla Brothers for purchasing a companyliery.

facts.text: In pass book of assessee, withdrawal of Rs. 1,00,000 after a few days, explained as given to Messrs. Birla Brothers for purchasing a colliery.

anchor.surface_text: In the pass book of the assessee, there was a withdrawal of Rs. 1,00,000 after a few days, and the assessee explained that the amount was given away to Messrs. Birla Brothers for purchasing a companyliery. The Income-tax Officer did number accept this explanation, and treated this amount as income of the assessee from some undisclosed source.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer did not accept explanation, treated amount as income from undisclosed source.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer did number accept this explanation, and treated this amount as income of the assessee from some undisclosed source. The order of the Income-tax Officer was companyfirmed by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner. On further appeal to the Tribunal, the explanation was accepted, and the amount was ordered to be excluded.

facts.text: Order of Income-tax Officer confirmed by Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

facts.text: On appeal to Tribunal, explanation accepted, amount ordered to be excluded.

anchor.surface_text: On further appeal to the Tribunal, the explanation was accepted, and the amount was ordered to be excluded. facts.text: Tribunal accepted that assessee had gold since 1918 purchased in Bombay when metal was cheap.

We have heard the parties at some length the examined the personal history of the appellant. On the whole, the impression left in our minds is that his explanation has the ring of truth. We accept it and exclude the sum of Rs. 72,523 from the assessment.

facts.text: Tribunal examined personal history of the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: We have heard the parties at some length the examined the personal history of the appellant. On the whole, the impression left in our minds is that his explanation has the ring of truth. We accept it and exclude the sum of Rs. 72,523 from the assessment. facts.text: Commissioner of Income-tax applied for a reference.

anchor.surface_text: We accept it and exclude the sum of Rs. 72,523 from the assessment. The Commissioner of Income-tax then applied for a reference, and the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, Calcutta Bench, which had by then changed, referred the case on the above stated question. facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, Calcutta Bench referred the case on the question.

facts.text: High Court called for supplementary statement under section 66(4).

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of Calcutta called for a supplementary statement of the case under section 66 4 , the directed the Tribunal to draw up and to forward to the companyrt a supplementary statement as to the manner in which the Appellate Bench of the Tribunal examined the personal history of the appellant. facts.text: Supplementary statement submitted by original Judicial Member and an Accountant Member who had not heard the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: This supplementary statement of the case was submitted by the original Judicial Member and an Accountant Member, who had number heard the appeal. They companysulted the previous Accountant Member, and stated that he had agreed with what was stated in the supplementary statement. It is needless to say that the Tribunal was somewhat vague in its replies to the questions which had been put but they sent for the assessee again the examined him as to what had transpired at the hearing a year and a half earlier,

facts.text: High Court held there was no material before Tribunal that assessee purchased gold in 1918 sold in year of account.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, after examining the matter from various angles and expressing disapprobation of the way in which the supplementary statement was submitted, held that there was numbermaterial before the Tribunal on which it companyld be said that the assessee has purchased gold in the year 1918, which he sold in the year of account. In our opinion, this was a perfectly simple case, in which a question of law hardly arose.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that Tribunal believed assessee's statement, which is material for the finding.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal had believed the assessees word in view of his companyduct and past history, such as they had been able to see. Where the assessees statement is believed, there is obviously material on which the finding is based and to seek for other material is tantamount to saying that a statement made by an assessee in number material on which a finding can be given.
